messages.text: <@U04MWF131V0> has joined the channel

"Nullable Infrastructure"
The blog post we discussed just now
<https://www.jamesshore.com/v2/blog/2018/testing-without-mocks>

*-> Nullable = "Kill Switch -> go to void"*
  - Adapter should have no "interesting stuff"
     extract "interesting stuff" and test that accordingly
  + refactoring friendly?
    Nullable is close to real adapter
  + move behaviour closer to production code
  - Nullable is in Production COde
  James :heart: manual DI and hates IOC
   Lots of mocks/stubs/fakes in Setup tells you -> bad design

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
I did some homework over night :/

Nullables =  Imperative Shell - Functional Core
Nullables are working well in the A-Frame architecture, less in Hexagonal or Onion. 
In Nullables there are no interfaces 
No mocks, fakes etc needed.

With Nullables we get closer to the edge. Further than mocks, fakes, stubs, ...
Nullables lead to simpler structures, than Ports+Adapters.

PS
Reminds me of some application architectures where I saw „Onion Overengineering“,  
 -> Nullables approach is very pragmatic (what I like) 
Like <https://victorrentea.ro/blog/overengineering-in-onion-hexagonal-architectures/|https://victorrentea.ro/blog/overengineering-in-onion-hexagonal-architectures/>

PS2: the series 
<https://youtu.be/DGQl8Wg4y4M|https://youtu.be/DGQl8Wg4y4M>

attachments.fallback: Victor Rentea: Overengineering in Onion/Hexagonal Architectures
attachments.title: Overengineering in Onion/Hexagonal Architectures
attachments.text: Clean Architecture, Onion Architecture, and Hexagonal Architecture (aka Ports-and-Adapters) have become the norm for backend system design today. Powerful influencers have promoted these architectures without stressing enough that they are (overly)complex, exhaustive blueprints that need …

attachments.title: Nullables & A-Frame Architecture with Ted M. Young (Part 1)

Nullables lead to simpler structures, than Ports+Adapters.

PS
Reminds me of some application architectures where I saw „Onion Overengineering“,  
 -> Nullables approach is very pragmatic (what I like) 
Like <https://victorrentea.ro/blog/overengineering-in-onion-hexagonal-architectures/|https://victorrentea.ro/blog/overengineering-in-onion-hexagonal-architectures/>

PS2: the series 
<https://youtu.be/DGQl8Wg4y4M|https://youtu.be/DGQl8Wg4y4M>

attachments.title: Welcome!
attachments.text:
SoCraTes Day is an International Conference for Software Craft and Testing, a single-day version of the full SoCraTes Conferences. It provides an ideal setting for speaking to and coding with other talented and engaged developers, letting us learn from and with each other.



Friday, 16 September, 2022



09.00 – 17.00



Ergon Informatik AG, 



Merkurstrasse 43, 



8032 Zürich



Register Here







In case you are not yet registered, get on our mailing list!



Info, Updates & Contact



The latest news and updates shall be posted on Twitter under @SoCraTesDay_CH.






In our Wiki you can find ideas for presentations, our Code of Conduct, rules and advice. With any further questions you may have, please contact us via email.



History



SoCraTes Conference is an International Software Craft and Testing Conference. Having started in Germany, the initiative rapidly grew and spread across Europe. In Switzerland we even have two annual events, SoCraTes Day (early autumn) and SoCraTes Conference (late winter). During these events we have met amazing people, learned a lot, made new friends. We are proud to be part of this family.



Our Amazing Sponsors







Partner Conferences




		Austria:SoCraTes Days Linz
	
	
		England:SoCraTes UK
	
	
		Germany:SoCraTes Conference
	
	
		Romania:I T.A.K.E. Unconference
	

		Belgium:SoCraTes BE
	
	
		Finland: CodeFreeze
	
	
		Greece:Agile Crete meets SoCraTes
	
	
		Spain:SoCraTes Canaries
	

		Chile:SoCraTes Chile
	
	
		France:SoCraTes France
	
	
		Italy:SoCraTes Italy
	
	
		Switzerland:SoCraTes Conference

messages.text: :question:Are there any pics, links, or notes from the *Performance Testing* session? I would be really interested in those, as I wasn't able to attend the session!

elements.text: Are there any pics, links, or notes from the
Performance Testing
session? I would be really interested in those, as I wasn't able to attend the session!
Hi
there were no pictures, because it was a discussion. I'll try to summarize here:

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_list","elements":[{"type":"rich_text_section","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"there are different flavors of performance testing: load, endurance, volume testing and many more depending on what is needed to be answered\/discovered; they reveal different problems: e.g with endurance\/soak testing memory leaks usually pop up;"}]},{"type":"rich_text_section","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"it is best if we can test on a production-like hardware, but if we can't, then the test env should be proportional with the production one; however we should always be aware of the risks and that extrapolation will never be precise and never the same;"}]},{"type":"rich_text_section","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"usually having \"proportional\" test env with lower resources may reveal some problems faster; by proportional we mean some general known correlations e.g. cpu vs memory; depends on what we measure;"}]},{"type":"rich_text_section","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"how do we calculate the target load? the easiest way is to search the production logs: find the usual peaks; if our software has never been live,  then there are calculations based on estimated user visits, concurrency etc.;"}]},{"type":"rich_text_section","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"we should be aware that users may not be the same as what we measure (e.g. requests per second), because one user may create multiple requests, so we should know our app: how end-user activities translate to requests\/second, or kb\/s if it is a streaming app etc.;"}]},{"type":"rich_text_section","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"we can do performance test on different levels: e.g. we can use our junit tests to see how performant is our algorithm; answer questions such as how long is the data processed from point A to point B, start up \/ shut down of a service, etc.;"}]},{"type":"rich_text_section","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"when we do load testing usually we are searching for a tipping point when the throughput cannot be increased more and response time is still acceptable; but how can we find this point if we are testing in an easily scalable environment? then our focus changes to detecting the metrics triggering the scaling, so we can improve them and reduce the need for scaling and save money, resources etc.;"}]},{"type":"rich_text_section","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"depending on the system there are usual issues that pop up and we firstly look for e.g. the load balancing configuration, db indexing and so on;"}]}],"style":"bullet","indent":0,"offset":0,"border":0}

elements.text:
I think I haven't missed anything, but feel free to contribute or contact me for more discussions.
I would like to thank Muriel again for accepting to host this session with me.

elements.text: Here is the code from Warmup Game of Life using Scheme/Lisp

elements.Raw:
{"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":";
; Unit test framework for scheme
; see "},{"type":"link","url":"http://c2.com/cgi/wiki?SchemeUnit"},{"type":"text","text":"
;
(define (reporterr msg)
    (error (string-append "ERROR: " msg))
)
(define (assert msg b)
    (if (not b) (reporterr msg))
)
(define (asserteq msg a b)
    (assert msg (> 0.0001 (abs (- a b))))
)

; rules define the next iteration/generation
; < 2 neighbours -> dies
; - 2 neighbours -> it stays alive
; - 3 neighbours -> it stays alive
; > 3 neighbours -> dies
; - 3 neighbours -> is born
; evaluation for all at once 

(define ALIVE "alive")
(define DEAD "dead")

(define (-next-state-for-dead number-of-neighbouring-cells)
  (if (eq? number-of-neighbouring-cells 3)
      ALIVE 
      DEAD))

(define (-next-state-for-alive number-of-neighbouring-cells)
  (if (or (eq? number-of-neighbouring-cells 2)
          (eq? number-of-neighbouring-cells 3))
      ALIVE
      DEAD))

(define (next-state current-state number-of-neighbouring-cells)
  (if (string=? current-state DEAD)
      (-next-state-for-dead number-of-neighbouring-cells)
      (-next-state-for-alive number-of-neighbouring-cells)))

(assert "live cell should die with 1 neighbour"
    (string=? "dead" (next-state "alive" 1)))

(assert "live cell should be alive with 2 neighbours"
    (string=? "alive" (next-state "alive" 2)))

(assert "live cell should be alive with 3 neighbours"
    (string=? "alive" (next-state "alive" 3)))

(assert "live cell should die when 4 neighbours"
    (string=? "dead" (next-state "alive" 4)))

(assert "dead cell should stays dead with 1 neighbour"
    (string=? "dead" (next-state "dead" 1)))

(assert "dead cell should stay dead with 2 neighbours"
    (string=? "dead" (next-state "dead" 2)))

(assert "dead cell should come alive 3 neighbours"
    (string=? "alive" (next-state "dead" 3)))

(assert "dead cell should stay dead with 4 neighbours"
    (string=? "dead" (next-state "dead" 4)))

; grid of cells
; cell has 8 neighbours

(define (count-neighbours grid)
  0)
  
(assert "for empty grid there are no neighbours"
    (= 0 (count-neighbours (list))))"}]}

Dear <#C2R198BRC|socrates_ch> participants. I just had a call with the Haus der Begegnung. They told me that they want more guests like us! In case you are looking for a location for a private or company event, just ping them! They would be happy to hear from you :blush:

In case you are not convinced yet, join us for SoCraTes Conference Switzerland 2024 and try the experience again! :grin:
